title: Analysis Deep‑Dive
description: Learn how to open and interpret Phage Explorer’s analysis overlays.

steps.title: Open the command palette
steps.content: Analyses are opened from the command palette. Press : (colon) any time to bring it up, then type an analysis name.

steps.title: Search for analyses
steps.content: Try typing “GC skew”, “complexity”, or “promoter”. The palette groups commands by category and respects your experience level.

steps.title: GC skew overlay
steps.content: GC skew highlights replication/packaging asymmetries. Peaks and troughs often mark origin‑like regions or structural modules.

steps.title: Sequence complexity
steps.content: Complexity (Shannon entropy) drops in low‑diversity regions such as repeats or highly constrained genes.

steps.title: Promoter / RBS motifs
steps.content: Promoter marks indicate likely transcription start regions. Clusters can suggest operons or early/late transcription blocks.

steps.title: Repeats / palindromes
steps.content: Repeat overlays flag palindromic or duplicated motifs. These can be recombination sites or regulatory hairpins.

steps.title: Dot plot & self‑similarity
steps.content: Dot plots show internal repeats and block duplications. Diagonal stripes off the main diagonal indicate duplicated segments.

steps.title: CGR & Hilbert maps
steps.content: CGR (Chaos Game Representation) and Hilbert curves visualize k‑mer signatures. Similar phages cluster in pattern space.

steps.title: HGT tracer
steps.content: Horizontal gene transfer hotspots are flagged by atypical k‑mer and codon signatures. Use this to spot modular swaps.

steps.title: Tropism & receptors
steps.content: Tropism overlays summarize predicted receptor targets and tail‑fiber signals. High‑confidence hits show likely host range.

steps.title: Learn the theory
steps.content: If any concept feels unfamiliar, open Beginner Mode’s Learn menu for foundational modules and glossary links.
